awd_titl_txt: SI2-SSI: SAGEnext: Next Generation Integrated Persistent Visualization and Collaboration Services for Global Cyberinfrastructure
awd_abstract_narration:
Cyberinfrastructure runs the gamut - from computing, networks, data stores, instruments, observatories, and sensors, to software and application codes - and promises to enable research at unprecedented scales, complexity, resolution, and accuracy. However, it is the research community that must make sense of all the data being amassed, so the SAGEnext (Scalable Adaptive Graphics Environment) framework is an innovative user-centered platform that connects people to their data and colleagues, locally and remotely, via tiled display walls, creating a portal, or wide-aperture "digital lens," with which to view their data and one another. It enables Cyber-Mashups, or the ability to juxtapose and integrate information from multiple sources in a variety of resolutions, as easily as the Web makes access to lower-resolution images today. 

SAGEnext expands on a vibrant partnership among national and international universities, supercomputer centers, government laboratories and industry; 100 institutions worldwide use the current version of SAGE. For computational scientists, from such diverse fields as biology, earth science, genomics, or physics, SAGEnext will transform the way they manage the scale and complexity of their data. For computer scientists, SAGEnext is a platform for conducting research in human-computer interaction, cloud computing, and advanced networking. SAGEnext capabilities, integrating visualization application codes, cloud documents, stereo 3D, and new user-interaction paradigms, is unprecedented and heretofore not available, and will have a transformative effect on data exploration and collaboration, making cyberinfrastructure more accessible to end users, in both the laboratory and in the classroom. SAGEnext, integrated with advanced cyberinfrastructure tools, will transform the way today's scientists and future scientists manage the scale and complexity of their data, enabling them to more rapidly address problems of national priority - such as global climate change or homeland security - which benefits all mankind. These same tools can better communicate scientific concepts to public policy and government officials, and via museum exhibitions, to the general public.

por.por_cntn:
SAGE (Scalable Adaptive Graphics Environment) is the community standard for cyber-enabled, data-intensive, visual analytics and collaboration. The SAGE (Scalable Adaptive Graphics Environment) project originally started in 2004, and SAGE2 (Scalable Amplified Group Environment), its successor, is a web-based system that was introduced in 2014. SAGE2, like its predecessor SAGE, has become the de facto operating system for managing Big Data on tiled walls, providing the scientific community with persistent visualization and collaboration services for global cyberinfrastructure.

SAGE2 is a scalable solution that enables local and remote collaborators to view and interact with arbitrary digital media content on any resolution screen, from a single monitor to a tiled display wall. SAGE2 is an open-source, web-based, user-centered platform for local and/or distributed small or large groups of researchers, educators and students to communicate information and ideas as if they were in the same room. Via wireless, users can simultaneously connect to display walls with their devices, share laptop screens, transfer local documents to the wall using a drag-and-drop interface, access web pages, share local documents with remote users, and use a mouse pointer, wand and/or keyboard to interact with content.

While other systems exist to address some of the challenges of displaying rich information on tiled display walls and/or enable multi-user interaction from heterogeneous devices, SAGE2 presents unified software that enables various forms of collaboration and data exploration, making it an ideal framework across a wide range of disciplines in academia, supercomputer centers, government research laboratories, and industry. Today, SAGE2 has a large and active user community, with over 4,000 users located at approximately 800 sites (with multiple sites and users at large institutions) in over 18 countries.

SAGE2 is being developed by the Laboratory for Advanced Visualization & Applications (LAVA) at the University of Hawaiʻi at Mānoa (UHM) and the Electronic Visualization Laboratory (EVL) at the University of Illinois Chicago (UIC).

Intellectual Merit: Our Nation already invests in network-connected, middleware-enabled cyberinfrastructure to generate and disseminate petabytes (ultimately exabytes) of data among researchers worldwide. What is missing, however, is a globally integrated collaborative work environment to facilitate human-computer interaction and computer-supported collaborative work. SAGE2 contributes to the entire scientific enterprise from end-to-end, which NSF calls the cyberinfrastructure ecosystem?s "missing middle" ? i.e., the links between data sources and repositories to end-users? abilities to discover, publish, share, integrate, collaborate and reuse. For researchers in such diverse disciplines as geoscience, disaster response, bioscience, cosmology, atmospheric science, chemistry, computer science, medicine and art, SAGE2 is having a transformative effect on data exploration and collaboration, making cyberinfrastructure more accessible to end users in both the laboratory and in the classroom.

Broader Impacts: SAGE2 provides scientists and students with better technologies in the laboratory and classroom than they have at home, fostering greater knowledge and understanding. It is transforming the way today?s scientists and future scientists manage the scale and complexity of their data, enabling them to more rapidly address problems of national priority ? such as global climate change or disaster response ? which benefits all mankind. It also provides undergraduate and graduate students with research experiences involving advanced technologies that makes them desirable when they graduate and enter the workforce. These same tools help communicate scientific concepts to public policy and government officials, and via museum exhibitions, to the general public.

Images (1 of )
  • A prototype of how neurobiologists at University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign and Northwestern University might use SAGE2 to view a data pipeline - from raw video to a temporal dynamics map of neuronal populations to the dynamics of brain circuits - to understand how our brain works.
    Image courtesy of the UIC Electronic Visualization Laboratory.
    Royalty-free (unrestricted use)
    Jason Leigh
    SAGE2 Creates a Neuroscience Collaboration Space
  • The Continuum research instrument and SAGE2 create a multi-collaboration classroom space for students to work on group projects.
    UIC Electronic Visualization Laboratory.
    Royalty-free (unrestricted use)
    Jason Leigh
    Continuum and SAGE2 Create a Multi-Collaboration Space
  • The University of Illinois Chicago holds an annual Images of Research contest to select images representing the breadth and diversity of research at UIC. The jury views 100 images - photographs, video, artwork, digital imaging, and computer simulations - using SAGE2 in the CAVE2.
    UIC Electronic Visualization Laboratory.
    Royalty-free (unrestricted use)
    Jason Leigh
    SAGE2 used by Jury to Select Best Campus Research Images
  • A prototype of JupyterLab integrated with SAGE2 enables researchers to share their Jupyter Notebooks and cells (sections of notebooks) and simultaneously collaborate with colleagues. When the Notebook is updated, shared cells are also updated.
    UIC Electronic Visualization Laboratory.
    Royalty-free (unrestricted use)
    Jason Leigh
    SAGE2 Integrated with Scientists' Notebooks
  • Graduate students collaborate on SAGE2 development while sitting in front of a tiled display workspace in a meeting room.
    UIC Electronic Visualization Laboratory.
    Royalty-free (unrestricted use)
    Jason Leigh
    SAGE2 in a Small Collaboration Room
  • Twenty-eight researchers at the Hawai'i Workshop on Trans-Pacific Visualization R&E (HI-Vision) use SAGE2 to brainstorm new applications requiring large display walls, in the areas of Renewable Energy, Coral Ecology, Water Resource Management, Disaster Response, and the Creative Arts and Culture.
    UHM Laboratory for Advanced Visualization & Applications
    Royalty-free (unrestricted use)
    Jason Leigh
    Trans-Pacific Collaboration Uses SAGE2 Post-It Notes to Brainstorm
